Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Engineering Ralstonia eutropha to Produce mcl-PHAs From Low Cost Feedstocks

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the project I was able to create and test four different 
plasmid mediated operons and assay them for PHB and protein content.  PHB granules were synthesized using the PHB operon from Ralstonia eutropha, but when any additional genes were added in an attempt to control size size distribution of the granules both the levels of protein and the amount of PHB were negatively effected, lowering both levels far below the wild type strains. Other work was done to confirm results from previous experiments that was not properly studied, but the new operons expressed had a detrimental impact on the PHB production process and did not have theesired outcome.  

Even though the results did not succeed in accomplishing the goals of the project, useful information can be taken away from the data and used in future studies working with PHA granules in R. eutropha.  Additional constructs were made adding to the tools available for the research lab where the experiments were conducted. Even though the project did not achieve the desired results, knowledge was gained. There are many ideas of ways to control the polydispersity of small granule sizes and shapes, and I was able to eliminate a few of the methods that will not work.

In addition to the data from the experiments, my skills as a researcher were enhanced and the experience of working in a lab in a foreign country was invaluable.  On many occasions the techniques used there were much different than those I was accustomed to, which helped to open my world up to new ways of thinking and overcoming problems faced during research.  I was a much more competent scientist after the project than I was starting out, and was able to make some life long connections across the world at the same time.


Last Modified: 01/31/2013
Modified by: Dan Rouse
